items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent and Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water. The level of Derwent Water remains high and is only receding very slowly. Lake levels are expected to continue to fall under a mostly showery regime today, Christmas Day and tomorrow Boxing Day though with further heavy rainfall forecast from the early hours on Wednesday 27th December 2023 further river response is likely and the level of Derwent Water is likely to rise again with further flooding possible.
 
Flooding is possible for locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the shores of Derwent Water.

We will continue to monitor the forecasts and re-issue this alert and associated warnings if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Churn and its tributaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are falling on the River Churn however continued flooding of low lying land and roads is expected, especially in the Cerney Wick area.  Persistent rain with the potential for heavy showers are forecast this afternoon (Monday). River levels may start to rise slightly later today, although this is not expected to be significant. Further rainfall is forecast for Wednesday.

We are monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. Persistent rain with the potential for heavy showers are forecast this afternoon (Monday). River levels may start to rise slightly later today, although this is not expected to be significant. Further rainfall is forecast for Wednesday.

We continue to monitor the situation and the forecast and will re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Severn Vyrnwy confluence
items.message:
River levels are falling but expected to rise again tonight at the Llanymynech and Cae Howel river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue. 
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre may also start to flood.
Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech 4.3m to 4.5m this evening, 25/12/2023; Cae Howel 4.3m to 4.5m this evening, 25/12/2023.
Further rainfall is forecast today. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, 26/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels continue to fall slowly but remain high around Low Marishes and Snainton Ings due to recent persistent rainfall. Areas most at risk include low lying land around Low Marishes and Yedingham. River levels in Malton are continuing to fall below levels of concern although high groundwater remains an issue and further wet weather is expected this week. We continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00pm on Monday 25/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. Persistent rain with the potential for heavy showers are forecast this afternoon (Monday). River levels may start to rise slightly later today, although this is not expected to be significant. Further rainfall is forecast for Wednesday.

We continue to monitor the situation and the forecast and will re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Lower Frome and tributaries
items.message:
River levels at our East Stoke gauge remain high but are slowly falling and our Stinsford gauge levels are also falling slowly, but this alert is likely to remain in force for at least the next 2 days.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels in the area. The forecast is for light rain showers today and tomorrow. 

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 4 PM on 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Shropshire
items.message:
River levels have peaked at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property roads and farmland is expected to continue.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn bankfull at White Abbey. 
Crew Green peaked at 6.17m this morning, 25/12, Predicted Peaks:- Montford 5.4m to 5.9m tonight 25/12, Welshbridge 3m to 3.4m tomorrow, 26/12, Buildwas 4.0m to 4.5m tomorrow night, 26/12, Bridgnorth 3.1m to 3.6m Wednesday 27/12.   
Further rainfall is forecast during today. We expect river levels to remain high until 27/12/2023. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, 26/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels continue to fall very slowly but remain high at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.
We expect river levels to remain high and may rise again as a result of additional forecast rainfall over today. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, 26/12/23, or as the situation changes

items.description: Middle Avon and tributaries
items.message:
River levels remain high in the Middle Hampshire Avon and its Tributaries but are slowly receding.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Salisbury and Ringwood.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 4 PM on 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
"Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels have been falling on the River Ray following last weeks rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, particularly in the Islip area. Persistent rain with the potential for heavy showers are forecast this afternoon (Monday). River levels may start to rise slightly in the next day or so in response to this rainfall, although this rise is not expected to be significant. Further rainfall is forecast for Wednesday.

We are monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes."

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thames, Blunsdon Brook, Water Eaton Brook, Marston Meysey Brook, Share Ditch, Bydemill Brook, Westrop Brook, Downington Brook

items.message:
"Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels remain high on the River Thames and small tributaries around Calcott. Water is expected to sitting in low lying land and roads but the river is expected to be flowing within its banks. Persistent rain with the potential for heavy showers are forecast this afternoon (Monday). River levels may start to rise slightly in the next day or so in response to this rain, although this rise is not expected to be significantly. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. Further rainfall is forecast for Wednesday.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes."

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely until Wednesday 27th December. Water levels continue to remain high, but are expected to soon start to drop back down towards more normal levels. This is due to a natural tide-locking effect where high tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth restricts the normal drainage out to sea at low tide. The Broads are also impacted by high river flows and high groundwater levels, meaning that the tide-locking effect is taking longer to clear. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boatyards and Ferry Road in Horning. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will issue further messages if the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Hull catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Holderness Drain, Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels remain high on Beverley and Barmston Drain, Frodingham Beck, the River Hull and Roam Drain due to recent prolonged rainfall and elevated groundwater levels. Areas most at risk are around the rivers and drains between Frodingham Bridge and the Wilfholme area including low lying land around Hempholme. Further wet weather is expected this week and levels are expected to stay high for several days. We continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 08:00pm on Monday 25/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
"Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels have remained high on the middle to lower parts of the River Thame for some time, although they have started to lower over the last few days. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Thame, Stadhampton and Dorchester areas. Persistent rain with the potential for heavy showers are forecast this afternoon (Monday). River levels may start to rise slightly in the next day or so in response to this rain, although this rise is not expected to be significantly. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. Further rainfall is forecast for Wednesday.

We are monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes."

items.description: Lower River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels continue to fall slowly on the Lower River Derwent at Thornton Lock and Elvington due to recent persistent rainfall. Further wet weather is expected this week and we expect levels to remain high for several days. Levels at Buttercrambe and Stamford Bridge have continued to fall and are below levels of concern, but floodwater is likely to remain on low lying land for some time. We are monitoring levels closely and have staff checking flood defences in the area. Continue acting on your flood plan. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00pm on Monday 25/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Avon and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are remaining high in the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon and tributaries and additional significant contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels. These levels are slowly starting to recede.

Levels are forecast to remain above the Flood Alert level.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 4 PM on 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Piddle and tributaries
items.message:
River levels are remaining high but starting to recede on the River Piddle following the recent rainfall and additional contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels.

Flooding is possible at tributaries between Alton Pancras and Wareham.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels in the area. The forecast is for light rain showers today and tomorrow. 

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 4 PM on 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels on the Chertsey Bourne are falling, but will remain responsive to further rainfall due to the already saturated ground. Further  rainfall is forecast for the next 48 hours. Therefore, the flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue in the Free Prae Road area over the next few days. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/12/2023, or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels have risen on the River Dee in response to overnight rainfall and are expected to continue rising throughout the day today.
Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington from this morning, 25/12/2023.
Townfield Lane at Farndon is likely to become cut off from 04:00 PM today.
Due to further rainfall forecast later this week, river levels are expected to remain high and continue to result in a risk of flooding to low lying land and roads through to Friday 29/12/2023.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 on 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.41m and is falling slowly. This level is being maintained by water being pumped off the moor.

The pumping station drain level is 7.87m and falling steadily in response to pumping activities. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.30m, from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, and from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m. Property flooding is expected when this level exceeds 8.35m.

Monday, Christmas day, will see periods of wet and unsettled weather. A sustained period of wet weather will impact the area from late on Tuesday evening through the early hours and into Wednesday.

We are currently pumping at Westover and Huish Episcopi pumping stations and will continue to clear as much water from the moors as river levels allow. Please remain mindful of local water levels and do not attempt to drive, cycle or walk through flood water.

Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on closed roads.

This message will be updated by 10am on Tuesday 26/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Monday 25th December, until tomorrow morning. Water levels continue to remain high but are expected to soon start to drop back down to more normal levels.  The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will issue further messages if the situation changes.  We will update this message by 12 noon tomorrow, Tuesday 26th December.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from today, Monday 25th December, until tomorrow morning. Water levels continue to remain high, but are expected to soon start to drop back down to more normal levels.  The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will issue further messages if the situation changes.  We will update this message by 12 noon tomorrow, Tuesday 26th December.

items.description: The Suffolk coast at Southwold
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hambledon
items.message: In Hambledon, groundwater levels are very high and continue to slowly rise. Since Tuesday 19/12/2023, the level at our borehole at Whitedale Farm has risen by 33cm. Cellar flooding is affecting a number of properties on West and East Street. Groundwater is inundating the sewerage system and water is beginning to push up through manholes. Flood water is affecting Fareham Road, and the football pitch is being affected by a mixture of groundwater and sewerage. From today (22/12/2023) until Sunday (24/12/2023), mostly dry weather is forecast. Groundwater levels are expected to peak over the weekend. From Monday 25/12/2023 to Tuesday 26/12/2023, there is a return to unsettled weather with up to 20mm of rain forecast in Hampshire. An increased number of properties in Hambledon are expected to experience cellar flooding when further heavy rain affects the area. We are liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group and continue to monitor the situation. If you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on 27/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels are high and fairly stable. The Idsworth and Chalton Lavants are both flowing. Water is affecting the ford in Rowlands Castle and minor flooding impacts are affecting roads in the area. Pumps which prevent water from entering property will be required for a small number of properties. Surface water flooding may occur during heavier rain events. From today (22/12/2023) until Sunday (24/12/2023), the weather is forecast to be mostly dry. However, from Monday (25/12/2023) to Tuesday (26/12/2023), the weather turns more unsettled again with up to 20mm forecast in Hampshire. Groundwater levels are expected to remain high for the next few weeks. Increased road and cellar flooding is likely after the next heavy rainfall event. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please continue to be prepared. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 27/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are slowly rising in response to recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole in Longacre in the Lambourn Valley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few days by flooding from groundwater.
The groundwater level at Longacre is higher than normal for this time of year and levels are slowly rising. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 29/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Churnet and River Tean
River Hull Central catchment

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Beverley and Barmston Drain

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Hull due to recent rainfall, high groundwater levels and the effect of the tides. Flooding may affect locations near the Beverley and Barmston Drain and River Hull, with low lying land expected to be most affected, including the central River Hull area around Arram, Tickton, Beverley, and Dunswell. Further wet weather is expected this week and levels are expected to remain high for a number of days. We are in the area operating pumping stations and checking defences, as well as operating flood defences across the wider catchment area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00pm on Monday 25/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels have risen at the Torksey gauge as a result of high tides. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. We expect levels to remain high through the Christmas period and we are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00 tomorrow morning, 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Exe area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Exe, River Batherm, River Lowman, River Haddeo

items.message:
Flooding is possible from the afternoon of Sunday 24th December with river levels remaining high on Monday.
There has been rainfall in the River Exe area, with more rain forecast. This has meant that the River Exe is now rising.
There will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river.
We expect the river to remain high throughout Monday 25th December though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not expected to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Tuesday 26th December or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Trent in Derbyshire
items.message:
"River levels have risen and remain high at the Shardlow river gauge as a result of frontal rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues to be possible from today, 25/12/23, for the next 48 hours.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
We expect river levels to remain high, we are closely monitoring the situation.    
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning by 10am 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes."

items.description: Upper River Tamar
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
Flooding remains possible today 25th December through to Wednesday 27th December. 

River levels on the Tamar remain high. The persistent rain that has fallen in North Cornwall and West Devon over the past 24 hours caused the River Tamar to rise overnight and will remain high through to Monday evening, 25th December.

With bands of heavy rain through 26th and 27th December river levels may fall before rising again later on the 26th  but remain high resulting in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river.  

A weather warning for heavy rain remains in force for Wednesday 27th December. This may lead to additional flood alerts and possibly flood warnings being issued.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We continue to monitor and forecast river levels and have staff in the area operating pumps at Bridgerule, checking for and clearing blockages. 

This message will be updated by 12pm on Christmas Day, or earlier if the situation changes. 

Issued from river levels at Tamarstone and Crowford Bridge.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Lilbourne gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this evening 25/12/23, and into tomorrow 26/12/23.  Flooding is likely to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.   
We expect river levels to remain high today and tomorrow.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow 26/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Derwent in Derbyshire
items.message:
"River levels have risen and remain high at the Church Wilne river gauge as a result of frontal rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible to continue from today, 25/12/2023 and over the next 48 hours.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Church Wilne, Draycott, and Wilne Lane between Draycott and Sawley.
We expect river levels to remain high.We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning by 10am 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes."

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high but have been slowly falling on the River Windrush, however continued flooding of low lying land and roads is expected, especially in the Bourton area. Persistent rain with the potential for heavy showers are forecast this afternoon (Monday). River levels may start to rise slightly later today, although this is not expected to be significant. Further rainfall is forecast for Wednesday.

We are monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings, avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Low lying properties in the Upper Hull catchment
items.message: River levels in the Upper River Hull catchment remain high due to recent rainfall and elevated groundwater levels. Areas most at risk include the River Hull and tributaries at Frodingham, Hempholme, Wilfholme and Burshill. Further wet weather is expected this week and levels are expected to remain high for several days as groundwater is yet to peak in some areas. West Beck is also particularly high. We are operating pumps in the area and continue to monitor the situation. Put your flood plan into action, avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 8:00pm on Monday 25/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels remain high in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is expected on the Hundred Foot (Ouse) Washes for several days. This information is correct as of 3:00 pm on 25/12/23. The causeway at Earith may have some standing water on the road. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 1 cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 16cm of water on the road. Norfolk County Council have closed Welney causeway. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. Floodwater is travelling down the River Great Ouse towards the Ouse Washes which will keep levels high for several days. Avoid driving through floodwater. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 8 am tomorrow, 26/12/23.

items.description: River Wye in Derbyshire
items.message:
"River levels have risen at the Ashford river gauge as a result of frontal rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible to continue over the next 48 hours from 25/12/23.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Ashford and Bakewell areas.   
We expect river levels to remain high.We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning by 10am 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes."

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high, and close to the surface. Minor groundwater flood impacts are expected to continue, with water flowing on roads, in basements or under floorboards, and affecting the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean. Water could also affect the B2141 at Chilgrove. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days (up to and including 25/12/2023). Groundwater at Chilgrove's borehole, is expected to continue falling, and water on the B2141 might reduce slightly. At the East Dean borehole, groundwater will stay at the surface. Flood impacts are expected to remain until the middle of January, and potentially longer, or affecting more people if wet weather returns. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 27/12/2023

items.description: Lower River Calder catchment
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.
River levels have fallen below levels of concern on the River Calder. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours but no significant river response is expected today. Take care in case standing water remains on low lying footpaths or roads and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will reissue this Flood Alert if required.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the West of Dorset
items.message:
Groundwater levels have receded across the West of Dorset. The borehole at Kingston Russell remains stubbornly high, but all others are falling back to more normal levels.   
Check any property level flood resilience measures including pumps, flood barriers and airbrick covers that you may have in place and replenish stocks of sand bags. 
The weather forecast up to the New Year indicates that rainfall totals could reach 30 - 40mm on Wednesday and into Thursday, however this is unlikely to make a significant change in the generally downward trend in groundwater levels. A colder, dryer spell will herald the New Year with a more unsettled period possible later in the month.
Environment Agency staff will monitor groundwater levels over the holiday and this message will be updated every 48 hours or as the situation changes. The next update will be on Tuesday 26th December.

items.description: Exmoor Rivers
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Barle, River Exe, River Lyn, River Mole, River Bray

items.message:
Flooding is possible from the afternoon of Sunday 24th December with river levels remaining high on Monday.
There has been persistent rainfall in the Exmoor Rivers area. This has meant that the Exmoor Rivers are now rising.
There will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout Monday 25th December though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not expected to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Tuesday 26th December or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Barnstaple, Braunton, Ilfracombe and Combe Martin area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Caen, Bradiford Water, River Yeo

items.message:
Flooding is possible from the afternoon of Sunday 24th December with river levels remaining high on Monday.
There has been persistent rainfall in the area. This has meant that the North Devon Rivers are now rising.
There will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river.
We expect the river to remain high throughout Monday 25th December though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not expected to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Tuesday 26th December or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: River Vyrnwy at Melverley
items.message:
River levels are falling but expected to rise again tonight at the Llanymynech as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to continue. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Melverley including Melverley to Melverley Green and Ponthen to Melverley roads.Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech 4.3m to 4.5m this evening 25/12, Cae Howel 4.3m to 4.5 this evening 25/12, Crew Green 6m to 6.4m 25/12 midday today 25/12.   
Further rainfall is forecast during today.  We expect river levels to remain high until 26/12/2023.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please move possession and valuables off the ground or to safety.  
This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, 26/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Vyrnwy at Maesbrook
items.message:
River levels are falling but expected to rise again tonight at the Llanymynech as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding (of property) is expected to continue.  We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Maesbrook.
Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech 4.3m to 4.5m this evening, 25/12/2023; Cae Howel 4.3m to 4.5m this evening, 25/12/2023.
Further rainfall is forecast during today.  We expect river levels to remain high until 26/12/2023.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please move possession and valuables off the ground or to safety.  
This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, 26/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle River Mersey catchment including areas near Bramhall, Stockport, Sale, Altrincham and Urmston

floodArea.county: Cheshire East, Manchester, Salford, Stockport, Tameside, Trafford, Warrington

items.message:
River levels are currently falling on the River Mersey but are expected to rise again following further rainfall, today, 25/12/2023.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads around Micker, Cringle, Sinderland and Poynton Brooks and their tributaries.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are falling but are expected to rise above Flood Alert level again around 10:00 PM tonight, 25/12/2023.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM tomorrow on 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mersey Uplands catchment including Hyde, Ashton-under-Lyne, Denton, Stalybridge and Glossop

floodArea.county: Barnsley, Cheshire East, Derbyshire, Oldham, Stockport, Tameside

items.message:
River levels are currently falling in the River Mersey uplands but are expected to rise again following further rainfall, today, 25/12/2023.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads around the Rivers Goyt, Tame, Sett and Etherow and their tributaries.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are falling but are expected to rise above Flood Alert level again around 07:00 PM tonight, 25/12/2023.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM tomorrow on 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Above average rainfall has been measured between October and December 2023. Groundwater is high and close to the surface, but currently slowly falling at the Compton borehole. Minor groundwater flood impacts will continue, with springs affecting fields, the village green Stoughton, and rural roads including Stoughton main road, the road from East Marden and also between Cooks Lane and The Barley Mow, and the B2146 near Woodlands Lane, in Walderton. Very little rain is forecast for the next five days (up to and including 25/12/2023). Groundwater is expected to continue to slowly fall through to next week, and possibly through to the New Year. Groundwater flood impacts might reduce by a small amount by January. However, groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 27/12/2023

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have receded across Cranborne Chase. All of the indicator boreholes are falling back to more normal levels.   
Check any property level flood resilience measures including pumps, flood barriers and airbrick covers that you may have in place and replenish stocks of sand bags. 
The weather forecast up to the New Year indicates that rainfall totals could reach 30 - 40mm on Wednesday and into Thursday, however this is unlikely to make a significant change in the generally downward trend in groundwater levels. A colder, dryer spell will herald the New Year with a more unsettled period possible later in the month.
Environment Agency staff will monitor groundwater levels over the holiday and this message will be updated every 48 hours or as the situation changes. The next update will be on Tuesday 26th December.

items.description: River Bourne and tributaries
items.message:
River levels are remaining high at the Salisbury Bourne river gauge on the River Bourne due to the recent rainfall and additional contributions to river flow from rising groundwater levels. Levels at our Ebbesbourne Wake and Salisbury gauges are receding but remain high.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Bourne, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Aughton and Laverstock.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels in the area. The forecast is for light rain showers today and tomorrow.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 4PM on 26/12/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in villages surrounding Andover are high and continuing to rise in response to the rainfall received in December. Groundwater is affecting cellars in Appleshaw and Hatherden, the sewer network in Penton Mewsey, and the main road in Penton Grafton. The spring at Biddesden could begin to flow from Tuesday 26/12/2023. Cellar flooding in Penton Grafton, and groundwater emergence into Deacon and Down Road, Kimpton is possible from Thursday 28/12/2023. From today (22/12/2023) until Sunday 24/12/2023, dry weather is forecast. From Monday 25/12/2023 to Tuesday 26/12/2023, unsettled weather will return with up to 20mm forecast in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels will continue to rise. If not, we expect the level to peak between Christmas and New Year. Cellar flooding in Kimpton and surface water flooding in Thruxton could occur in early January 2024. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please remove valuables from cellars and ensure pumps used to reduce water levels can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 27/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: In Hursley, groundwater levels are high and have risen 47cm in the last 3 days. Groundwater will be affecting cellars in the south end of the village and at the Dolphin Inn pub, as well as impacting the sewerage network. From today (22/12/2023) until Sunday (24/12/2023), the weather is forecast to be dry. From Monday to Tuesday (26/12/2023), up to 20mm of rain is forecast in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects Hursley, then groundwater levels will continue to rise. If not, then we expect the level to peak within the next few days. During the next 5 days, it is possible that cellars in upper Hursley will begin to be affected. We continue to monitor the forecast and groundwater levels. Please remove valuables from cellars, and if you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 27/12/2023.

items.description: River Wye in Herefordshire
items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Wye as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the flooding of roads and farmland is expected over the next couple of days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford.
The river has peaked at Hay on Wye 2.83m last night, 24/12; at Bredwardine 4.78m last night, 24/12; Belmont 4,79m this morning, 25/12; Old Wye Bridge 4.29m this morning, 25/12; Predicted peaks:- Mordiford 4.4m to 4.5m this evening, 25/12; and Ross on Wye 3.7m to 4.0m this evening, 25/12.
Further rainfall is forecast during today. We currently expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday, 26/12.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, 26/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Wye in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Ross-On-Wye river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye.
 Predicted Peaks:- Ross on Wye 3.7m to 4.0m this evening 25/12, Lydbrook 4.3m to 4.5m over night to night, 25/12.   
  Further rainfall is forecast during today. We expect river levels to remain high until 26/12.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, 26/12/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Meon Valley from East Meon to Soberton
items.message: In the Meon Valley, groundwater levels are high but continue to slowly fall after a week of mostly dry weather. The Winterbourne has been flowing in Meonstoke for a couple of weeks and there is a small amount of water ponded around the electricity sub-station in Rectory Lane. From today (22/12/2023) until Sunday (24/12/2023), the weather is forecast to be dry. Groundwater levels are expected to continue falling during that time. However, from Monday (25/12/2023) to Tuesday (26/12/2023), the weather turns more unsettled again with up to 20mm forecast in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects the Meon Valley, groundwater levels will begin to rise again. Cellar flooding caused by groundwater remains a possibility this winter. Please remain prepared. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please check that they can operate effectively. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 27/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have fallen back in the West Wiltshire Downs, the Vale of Wardour and much of the Plain itself, however boreholes at Idmiston and Clarendon in the lower Bourne valley are still creeping up very slowly. 
Check any property level flood resilience measures including pumps, flood barriers and airbrick covers that you may have in place and replenish stocks of sand bags. 
The weather forecast up to the New Year indicates that rainfall totals could reach 30 - 40mm on Wednesday and into Thursday, however this is unlikely to make a significant change in the generally downward trend in groundwater levels. A colder, dryer spell will herald the New Year with a more unsettled period possible later in the month.
Environment Agency staff will monitor groundwater levels over the holiday and this message will be updated every 48 hours or as the situation changes. The next update will be on Tuesday 26th December.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Twyford and Hensting
items.message: In Twyford and Hensting, groundwater levels are high and continue to rise. In the next 3 days, cellar flooding may begin to affect a small number of properties in Twyford and Hensting. However, we are expecting levels to begin stabilising in the next 3 days. Levels may peak just below the level we expect impacts to occur. From today (22/12/2023) until Sunday (24/12/2023), the weather is forecast to be mostly dry. However, from Monday (25/12/2023) to Tuesday (26/12/2023), the weather turns more unsettled again with up to 20mm forecast in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels will continue to rise. Minor impact flooding to Hensting Lane could occur in the next 2 weeks. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on 27/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Vernham Dean, Upton and the Bourne Valley
items.message: In the Bourne Valley, groundwater levels are high and rising. At Vernham Dean, the current rate of rise is 22cm per day. Currently, groundwater is inundating the sewerage network in Stoke. In the next 5 days, groundwater may affect a small number of cellars and the sewerage system in Upton. However, the rate of rise is slowing and levels may peak before this occurs. We do not expect significant impacts to property at Vernham Dean, Hurstbourne Tarrant, Stoke or St Marybourne until later this winter. From today until Sunday (24/12/2023), dry weather is forecast. From Monday to Tuesday (26/12/2023), up to 20mm of rainfall is forecast. If heavy rain affects the Bourne Valley, groundwater levels will continue to rise. If not, we expect the level to peak between Christmas and New Year. We continue to monitor the forecast. In Upton, please remove any valuables from cellars and if you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they can operate. We advise all residents in the Bourne Valley to remain prepared. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 27/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Bramdean and Cheriton
items.message: In Bramdean and Cheriton, groundwater levels are high and continue to rise. Cellar flooding to a small number of properties in Cheriton is imminent. It is unlikely that cellar flooding will affect property in Bramdean for at least a couple of weeks. From today (22/12/2023) until Sunday (24/12/2023), the weather is forecast to be mostly dry. Groundwater levels in Bramdean and Cheriton are expected to peak in the next 3 days. However, from Monday (25/12/2023) to Tuesday (26/12/2023), the weather turns more unsettled again with up to 20mm forecast in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects the area, groundwater levels will continue to rise. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on 27/12/2023.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in East Kent
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Groundwater levels in East Kent are rising as a result of higher than average rainfall over the last three months. The Alkham Bourne is flowing, with large sections of upper and lower Nailbourne now also seeing flows. There are some flooding impacts being seen on low-lying land, roads and water infrastructure in and around the Elham Valley, Alkham, and Petham. Other communities in East Kent may also experience impacts this winter. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. 

Groundwater and river levels are expected to remain high until the Spring in 2024 and they are likely to respond to further rainfall. The weather forecast is largely dry until Christmas Day when we may see some further rainfall and unsettled weather towards the New Year. We continue to monitor the situation and are co-ordinating efforts with the local authorities and communities around the deployment of temporary defences. Our staff are maintaining and clearing key structures. This message will be updated by 28 December 2023, or as the situation changes. Search ‘Kent Groundwater Situation’ on gov.uk.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne
items.message: Groundwater levels in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne are high for the time of year. In the last 2 months, prolonged, much higher than average rain (310mm) was recorded at Broughton. Within Kings Somborne levels look like they have started to stabilise. Further up the valley levels are still rising and are expected to continue rising for at least another week. From today (22/12/2023) until Sunday 24/12/2023, the weather is forecast to be mostly dry. However, unsettled weather is expected to return from Monday 25/12/2023 to Tuesday 26/12/2023, with up to 20mm forecast in Hampshire. If heavy rain affects the area, then levels could rise further throughout the Christmas period and cellar flooding to a small number of properties along Winchester Road, central Kings Somborne and in Little Somborne would be possible before the New Year. Please remove valuables from cellars and if you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 27/12/2023.

items.description: Middle River Tamar
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Lyd, River Thrushel

items.message:
Flooding remains possible today 25th December through to Wednesday 27th December.   

River levels on the Tamar remain high. The persistent rain that has fallen in North Cornwall and West Devon over the past 24 hours caused the River Tamar to rise overnight and will remain high through to Monday evening, 25th December. 

With bands of heavy rain through 26th and 27th December river levels may fall before rising again later on the 26th  but remain high resulting in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river.  

A weather warning for heavy rain remains in force for Wednesday 27th December. This may lead to additional flood alerts and possibly flood warnings being issued. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We continue to monitor and forecast river levels and have staff in the area operating pumps at Bridgerule, checking for and clearing blockages.

This message will be updated by 12pm on Christmas Day, or earlier if the situation changes.

Issued from river levels at Canworthy Water.

items.description: Lower Exe area
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible from the afternoon of Sunday 24th December with river levels remaining high on Monday.
There has been rainfall in the River Exe area, with more rain forecast. This has meant that the River Exe is now rising.
There will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river.
We expect the river to remain high throughout Monday 25th December though no flooding to properties is forecast and warnings are not expected to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are constantly monitoring river levels. This message will be updated on Tuesday 26th December or earlier if the situation changes.
